oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Women College Presidents: Interviews about Journeys and Adaptations
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Switzer, Jo Young
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: While the progress of women into higher education presidencies is dramatic, it is also, in the words of one experienced woman president, “not exactly a lot!” In the 15 years from 1986 to 2001, the American Council on Education (ACE) reports that the percentage of women presidents increased from 9.5 to 21.1 (The American college president, 2002). Of these women, 26.8% led two-year institutions; 18.7% led baccalaureate schools; 20.3% led comprehensive universities; and only 13.3% headed doctorate-granting schools; with the remaining 14.8% guiding specialized schools.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Education Leadership Research Center, Texas A&M University
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Advancing Women in Leadership Journal; Vol. 21 (2006 Summer)
